column4: ok i have a problem with a program that wont install over apt ... and even if this may boil down to me having a too old PPC version, i still dont understand why it cant get a library in. The tool seems to rely on libgda2-common, but when i try to install that apt says "its already the latest version"
is this a common apt problem?
i mean, when it seems as you need a package, but it also seems as you have it
the program probabaly wants a later version which isn't currently available in your repositories
but apt says libgda2-common is already the latest version? (on my machine)
exactly, so what's the exact command error message when you try to install your program (use pastebin)
http://pastebin.ca/58461   Read from the top and down (as is usual in the western countries)
ok, looking, thanks for the tip :)
pastebin your sources.list and the output from 'apt-cache policy libgda2-common'
policy ? Uh ok whatever you say ....
i am trying to help here.  have i annoyed you in some way?
no, its just that apt-cache surprises me with its many weird options
ah, kk :)
okay lets see, i put them in the same paste:   http://pastebin.ca/58466   the sources come first.
that is wierd, have you done a "sudo apt-get update" recently?
yeah, i believe i did that just after commenting out some stuff in the sources 15 minutes ago ... but i could try again
btw someone said that "ubuntu0.1" looked fishy
no that's ok, although i thought it was supposed to be ubuntu1, ubuntu2 ...

but is the weird thing that it doesnt want to install libgda2-common (or that it complains that it needs it, when at the same time it says it has it) .... or did you see anything else that was weird too ?
yes, the wierd thing is that it says it says "Depends: libgda2-common (>= 1.1.99-1ubuntu0.1)" and yet you have "1.2.1-2ubuntu2~hoary1" installed
OK ... thanks for taking a look at it!
